content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

```julia
struct FloatWithUnits{T<:Real, U}
    value::T
    unit::U
end

Base.show(io::IO, fwu::FloatWithUnits) = print(io, fwu.value, " ", fwu.unit)
```

This `show` method for the `FloatWithUnits` struct will take an `IO` object (often just `STDout`) as the first argument and a `FloatWithUnits` instance as the second argument. It then prints out the value followed by a space and then the unit, using the `print` function which is more efficient than `println` for writing to an `IO` stream without starting a new line.
